author: Sruthisagar Yamunan
text:
With the Congress firming up its alliance with the DMK, the party headquarters Satyamurthy Bhavan witnessed unusual action on Sunday with hundreds of aspirants seeking ticket to contest in the coming Assembly polls.

To the surprise of workers, the aspirants cut across factions, including those who wanted to boycott the application process questioning its authenticity.

When the doors of the Congress office opened on Sunday morning, scores were waiting in queue to pay the nomination money of Rs. 5,000 to apply for a seat. Sources said those who turned up were primarily from southern districts.

The alliance with the DMK has clearly had an impact on Congress workers since the crowd began building up only on Saturday when the electoral pact was formalised.

Prospects bright

Sridhar, a party member from Thoothukudi, said the electoral prospects of the Congress were now bright. “In the southern districts, it is very hard to beat the DMK-Congress combination. We are very happy with the development,” he added, after filing his papers.

The rush for constituencies in southern districts seemed strategic as many felt it was in this belt that the DMK would allot most seats to the Congress.

An aspirant from Kanyakumari said the Congress lost the Lok Sabha election in the constituency because the party went alone and the minority votes were split due to a multi-cornered contest.

Meanwhile, TNCC president E.V.K.S. Elangovan said if required he would personally meet DMDK leader Vijayakant to convince him to join the DMK front.
